problem: 
new model msg received from server before step 3) hence gzweb thinks model already exists

problem: new model msg received from server before step 3) hence gzweb thinks model already exists

values.title: Manipulators not attached to spawned model

content.raw:
In translate mode with a model already selected, if you spawn a new model, the translation manipulators appear on top of the new model but not attached to it (so moving the manipulators doesn't move the model).

A few times the new model is spawned but the manipulators remain on the model where they were before, working fine.
content.html:
In translate mode with a model already selected, if you spawn a new model, the translation manipulators appear on top of the new model but not attached to it (so moving the manipulators doesn't move the model).

A few times the new model is spawned but the manipulators remain on the model where they were before, working fine.

values.title: Some models not showing unless "View Collisions" is selected

content.raw:
For example, running the [control model tutorial](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/1.3/intermediate/control_model) on gazebo looks fine from the beginning, but on gzweb nothing shows before "View Collisions" is selected.

This wasn't hapenning a few commits ago.

values.title: Error when inserting first simple shape

content.raw:
When the first simple shape (box/cylinder/sphere) is inserted, there's the following error on the server side:


```
#!bash

Error [Param.cc:146] Empty string used when setting a required parameter. Key[name]
Error [parser.cc:469] Unable to read attribute[name]
Error [parser.cc:688] Error reading element <model>
Error [parser.cc:348] Unable to read element <sdf>
Error [parser_urdf.cc:2608] Unable to call parseURDF on robot model
Error [parser.cc:299] parse as old deprecated model file failed.
Error [World.cc:1469] Unable to read sdf string[<sdf version ='1.4'><model name=''><pose>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose><link name ='link'><inertial><mass>1.0</mass></inertial><collision name ='collision'><geometry></geometry></collision><visual name ='visual'><geometry></geometry><material><script><uri>file://media/materials/scripts/gazebo.material</uri><name>Gazebo/Grey</name></script></material></visual></link></model></sdf>]
```

The error doesn't show for the shapes inserted afterwards.

values.title: Spawning multiple instances of a mesh causes WebGL error

content.raw:
Pull request #36 solved the issue of multiple meshes for many models, such as `bowl`, `beer` and `bookshelf`.

However, trying to spawn more than one instance of models such as `coke_can`,  `construction_cone` or `dumpster` now gives the following WebGL error:

*Error: WebGL: drawElements: bound vertex attribute buffers do not have sufficient size for given indices from the bound element array*
content.html:
Pull request #36 solved the issue of multiple meshes for many models, such as bowl, beer and bookshelf.

However, trying to spawn more than one instance of models such as coke_can, construction_cone or dumpster now gives the following WebGL error:

Error: WebGL: drawElements: bound vertex attribute buffers do not have sufficient size for given indices from the bound element array

the yellow sphere doesn't correspond to the mouse cursor but to the corner of the box

values.title: optimize initial loading of resources in browser

content.raw:
Now that we have many models and hence thumbnails, these images get downloaded as soon as users access gzweb, requiring them to download a up to MBs of data. It would be nice to reduce the amount of traffic sent to the client on load.

options:

* reduce thumbnail size

* load thumbnails on demand (e.g. when navigating the insert panel, or when a model gets added to the world tree)
content.html:
Now that we have many models and hence thumbnails, these images get downloaded as soon as users access gzweb, requiring them to download a up to MBs of data. It would be nice to reduce the amount of traffic sent to the client on load.

options:

  • reduce thumbnail size

  • load thumbnails on demand (e.g. when navigating the insert panel, or when a model gets added to the world tree)

content.raw:
Hi, all!

I'm trying to run the tutorial of turtulebot_simulator ( http://wiki.ros.org/turtlebot_simulator ) using gzweb.

I could run the launch `roslaunch turtlebot_gazebo turtlebot_empty_world.launch`, and I could see a turtlebot on gazebo sim.

Then I executed `./start_gzweb.sh`, and could see the ground of gazebo world, but no turtlebot has been found.

I know that in order to use custom model on gzweb, local model has to be deployed.
So, I executed some commands as follow:

```
export GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH=`rospack find turtlebot_description`/..:$GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH
cd /path/to/gzweb
./deploy.sh -m local
```

After this, I checked that `turtlebot_description` directory has been copied to `http/client/assets` folder.

How should I do next?

As you can see from this gzgui.js's excerpt, the round function modifies stats properties: 

GZ3D.Gui.prototype.round = function(stats, isColor, decimals)
{
  if (typeof stats === 'number')
  {
    stats = this.roundNumber(stats, isColor, decimals);
  }
  else // array of numbers
  {
    stats = this.roundArray(stats, isColor, decimals);
  }
  return stats;
};

Fix proposal:

GZ3D.Gui.prototype.roundArray = function(stats, isColor, decimals)
{ 
  var result = {}; 
  for (var key in stats)
  {
    if (stats.hasOwnProperty(key)) {
      if (typeof stats[key] === 'number')
      {
        result[key] = this.roundNumber(stats[key], isColor, decimals);
      }
    }
  }

  return result;
};

values.title: Bug: flawed comparisons in gzgui.js (setLight event)

content.html:
In the following excerpt:

guiEvents.on('setLight', function (prop, name, value)
      {
        if (value === undefined)
        {
          return;
        }

        var entity = that.scene.getByName(name);
        if (prop === 'diffuse')
        {
          entity.children[0].color = new THREE.Color(value);
        }
        else if (prop === 'specular')
        {
          entity.serverProperties.specular = new THREE.Color(value);
        }
        else if (prop === 'range')
        {
          entity.children[0].distance = value;
        }
        else if (prop === 'attenuation_constant')
        {
          // Adjust according to factor
          var factor = 1;
          if (entity instanceof THREE.PointLight)
          {
            factor = 1.5;
          }
          else if (entity instanceof THREE.SpotLight)
          {
            factor = 5;
          }
          value *= factor;

          entity.children[0].intensity = value;
        }
        else if (prop === 'attenuation_linear')
        {
          entity.serverProperties.attenuation_linear = value;
        }
        else if (prop === 'attenuation_quadratic')
        {
          entity.serverProperties.attenuation_quadratic = value;
        }

        // updating color too often, maybe only update when popup is closed
        that.scene.emitter.emit('entityChanged', entity);
      }
  );

you can observe that entity is compared twice against an instance of aTHREE.js light whereas it is an array containing two THREE.js objects.

Possible fix: use the following variable everywhere possible.

var lightObj = entity.children[0];

content.raw:
Because THREE.js light intensity is some factor divided by the attenuation constant of the light from the sdf file, the client light intensity decreases as the server light intensity increases, and vice et versa.
Taken from gziface.js:

```
  obj = this.scene.createLight(light.type, light.diffuse,
        light.attenuation_constant * factor,
        light.pose, range, light.cast_shadows, light.name,
        direction, light.specular, light.attenuation_linear,
        light.attenuation_quadratic);
```


Quick fix: THREE.js light intensity = some factor / attenuation constant
content.html:
Because THREE.js light intensity is some factor divided by the attenuation constant of the light from the sdf file, the client light intensity decreases as the server light intensity increases, and vice et versa. Taken from gziface.js:

  obj = this.scene.createLight(light.type, light.diffuse,
        light.attenuation_constant * factor,
        light.pose, range, light.cast_shadows, light.name,
        direction, light.specular, light.attenuation_linear,
        light.attenuation_quadratic);

Quick fix: THREE.js light intensity = some factor / attenuation constant

Because THREE.js light intensity changes on the client side are translated into attenuation constant changes on the server side, the intensity of directional lights (for which attenuation is meaningless) never change on server side.

Taken from gziface.js:

      var attenuation_constant = entity.children[0].intensity;
      // Adjust according to factor
      if (entity instanceof THREE.PointLight)
      {
        attenuation_constant *= 1.5;
      }
      else if (entity instanceof THREE.SpotLight)
      {
        attenuation_constant *= 5;
      }

      entityMsg.attenuation_constant = attenuation_constant;
      entityMsg.attenuation_linear = entity.serverProperties.attenuation_linear;
      entityMsg.attenuation_quadratic = entity.serverProperties.attenuation_quadratic;

      that.lightModifyTopic.publish(entityMsg);

Fix idea: store initial diffuse colors of directional lights and use THREE.js light intensity as a scalar that multiply every diffuse color component.

values.title: Lights are not updated when they change on the server

content.html:
As you can see from this gziface's excerpt, nothing is done when light properties change:

  var lightUpdate = function(message)
  {
    if (!this.scene.getByName(message.name))
    {
      var lightObj = this.createLightFromMsg(message);
      this.scene.add(lightObj);
      guiEvents.emit('notification_popup', message.name+' inserted');
    }
    this.gui.setLightStats(message, 'update');
  };

  lightTopic.subscribe(lightUpdate.bind(this));

Sketch of fix:

  var lightUpdate = function(message)
  {
    var entity = this.scene.getByName(message.name);
    if (!entity)
    {
      var lightObj = this.createLightFromMsg(message);
      this.scene.add(lightObj);
      guiEvents.emit('notification_popup', message.name+' inserted');
    } else {
      this.scene.updateLight(entity, message);
    }
    this.gui.setLightStats(message, 'update');
  };

  lightTopic.subscribe(lightUpdate.bind(this));

and 

GZ3D.Scene.prototype.updateLight = function(model, light)
{
  var direction, lightType;
  var lightObj = model.children[0];

  if (this.modelManipulator && this.modelManipulator.object &&
      this.modelManipulator.hovered)
  {
    return;
  }

  var matrixWorld;
  if (light.pose) {
    this.setPose(model, light.pose.position, light.pose.orientation);

    // needed to update light's direction
    model.updateMatrixWorld();
    var quaternion = new THREE.Quaternion(
         light.pose.orientation.x,
         light.pose.orientation.y,
         light.pose.orientation.z,
         light.pose.orientation.w);

    var translation = new THREE.Vector3(
         light.pose.position.x,
         light.pose.position.y,
         light.pose.position.z);

    matrixWorld = new THREE.Matrix4();
    matrixWorld.compose(translation, quaternion, new THREE.Vector3(1,1,1));
  }

  if (lightObj instanceof THREE.PointLight)
  {
    direction = null;
    lightType = this.POINT;
  }
  else if (lightObj instanceof THREE.SpotLight)
  {
    direction = light.direction;
    lightType = this.SPOT;
  }
  else if (lightObj instanceof THREE.DirectionalLight)
  {
    direction = light.direction;
    lightType = this.DIRECTIONAL;
  }

  if (light.diffuse) {
    var color = new THREE.Color();

    if (typeof(light.diffuse) === 'undefined')
    {
      light.diffuse = 0xffffff;
    }
    else if (typeof(light.diffuse) !== THREE.Color)
    {
      color.r = light.diffuse.r;
      color.g = light.diffuse.g;
      color.b = light.diffuse.b;
      diffuse = color.clone();
    }
    lightObj.color = light.diffuse;
  }
  if (light.specular) {
    // property not relevant in THREE.js
  }
  if (light.attenuation_constant) {
    lightObj.intensity = this.attenuationToIntensity(light.attenuation_constant, lightType);
  }
  if (light.attenuation_linear) {
    // property not relevant in THREE.js
  }
  if (light.attenuation_quadratic) {
    // property not relevant in THREE.js
  }
  if (light.range) {
    // THREE.js's light distance impacts the attenuation factor defined in the shader: 
    // attenuation factor = 1.0 - distance-to-enlighted-point / light.distance
    // Gazebo's range (taken from OGRE 3D API) does not contribute to attenuation; it is a hard limit
    // for light scope.
    // Nevertheless, we identify them for sake of simplicity.
    lightObj.distance = light.range; 
  }
  if (lightObj instanceof THREE.SpotLight) {
    if (light.spot_inner_angle) {
      // property not relevant in THREE.js
    }
    if (light.spot_outer_angle) {
      lightObj.angle = light.spot_outer_angle;
    }
    if (light.spot_falloff) {
      lightObj.exponent = light.spot_falloff;
    }
  }

  if (direction) {
    var dir = new THREE.Vector3(direction.x, direction.y,
        direction.z);
    model.direction.copy(dir);
    dir.applyMatrix4(matrixWorld); // localToWorld
    lightObj.target.position.copy(dir);
  } else if (light.type === this.POINT || light.type === this.SPOT) {
    var dir = new THREE.Vector3(0,0,0);
    dir.copy(model.direction);
    model.localToWorld(dir);
    lightObj.target.position.copy(dir);
  }
};

values.title: Generate insert menu automatically from database

content.raw:
Currently, the list of models in the insert menu is hard-coded. So if the user doesn't download the model database, the insert menu will display broken images as thumbnails and models can't be inserted.

Also, as new models are added to [gazebo_models](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/src), they should be automatically accommodated in the insert menu.
content.html:
Currently, the list of models in the insert menu is hard-coded. So if the user doesn't download the model database, the insert menu will display broken images as thumbnails and models can't be inserted.

Also, as new models are added to gazebo_models, they should be automatically accommodated in the insert menu.

In .world file we can define the cameraview's init pose like this, which Gzweb 1.2.0 seems to be ignoring for me.

     </scene>
+    <gui>
+     <camera name="camera_world_main">
+       <pose>57 15 1 0 0.05 1.4</pose>
+     </camera>
+    </gui>
   </world>

Manually chaging gzweb/http/client/gz3d.js like below works.

  // camera
  this.camera = new THREE.PerspectiveCamera(
      60, window.innerWidth / window.innerHeight, 0.1, 1000 );
- this.defaultCameraPosition = new THREE.Vector3(0, -5, 5);
+ this.defaultCameraPosition = new THREE.Vector3(57, 15, 1);
  this.resetView();

GZ3D.Scene.prototype.resetView = function()
{
  this.camera.position.copy(this.defaultCameraPosition);
  this.camera.up = new THREE.Vector3(0, 0, 1);
- this.camera.lookAt(new THREE.Vector3( 0, 0, 0 ));
+ this.camera.lookAt(new THREE.Vector3( 62, 22, 0 ));
  this.camera.updateMatrix();
};

Still, this resetView isn't effective when the web page is reloaded. Pressing Reset View button on Gzweb works.

So in summary, issues I'm seeing:

1) camera tag in SDF is ignored. 2) resetView in gzweb/http/client/gz3d.js does not work when the Gzweb web page is loaded.

content.raw:
See http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/8421/no-skyx-texture-on-gzweb/

One thing I didn't mention in the QA post that I still don't know is that without sky setting, Gzweb showed the color of the sky as white/light gray, while with sky it's blacked out, as pictures below. So I assume it's `<sky>` tag in SDF that's not yet taken by Gzweb but `<background>` tag is considered (see [the commit](https://github.com/tork-a/hakuto/commit/57b620eab18170938c43b8033435e3ce121f7cba) that is probably making the difference below).

With <sky> tag: ![with sky setting on gzweb](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1840401/7098153/fb4abcaa-df91-11e4-99ac-dac4f8d50808.png)

A [related ticket in downstream](https://github.com/tork-a/hakuto/issues/43#issuecomment-93603875).

content.raw:
Hi, all!

I'm trying to run the my gazebo model(evarobot) using gzweb.
I could run the launch  roslaunch evarobot_description demo.launch, and I could see an evarobot on gazebo sim but when I start gzweb I can't find the model to insert!

source /usr/share/gazebo-4-1/setup.sh
export GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH=`rospack find evarobot_description`:$GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH
cd /path/to/gzweb*

Then I executed ./start_gzweb.sh, and could see the ground of gazebo world, but no evarobot has been found.

How should I do next?

content.raw:
Should have posted to [here](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/1616/securing-setup-keys-step) first, woops

As I was reading through some new proposed [security guidelines](https://github.com/infosiftr/stackbrew/blob/docs/README.md#security) for official docker hub images, I realized our [Step-by-step Install](http://www.gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=install_ubuntu&cat=install) is still instructing people to use `http` for retrieving the singed keys for the Gazebo repository.

This is of course quite insecure and I would suggest we migrate to a better method. ROS has adjusted it [wiki install instructions](http://wiki.ros.org/indigo/Installation/Ubuntu) to use `https` by hosting the keys on in [rosdistro](https://github.com/ros/rosdistro) and piggybacking off GitHub's `https` certification. I would guess something quite similar ineffective could be done here with Bitbucket.

This would also aid in my effort in getting Gazebo an official DockerHub image.  
Thanks!
content.html:
Should have posted to here first, woops

As I was reading through some new proposed security guidelines for official docker hub images, I realized our Step-by-step Install is still instructing people to use http for retrieving the singed keys for the Gazebo repository.

This is of course quite insecure and I would suggest we migrate to a better method. ROS has adjusted it wiki install instructions to use https by hosting the keys on in rosdistro and piggybacking off GitHub's https certification. I would guess something quite similar ineffective could be done here with Bitbucket.

This would also aid in my effort in getting Gazebo an official DockerHub image.
Thanks!

content.raw:
When building the gzweb project from source, icons used selecting objects within the web GUI fail to be generated when built on a headless machine. The need for x server session to host the gazebo rendering used when generating the icon set should be avoided.

In this case, the gzweb docker image built from OSRF's automatic registry on Docker Hub can not create icon sets, leaving the gzweb interface running from container using the distributed images rather devastated:  

https://hub.docker.com/r/osrf/gazebo/  

![Screenshot from 2015-08-13 19:26:47.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/4283563600-Screenshot_from_2015-08-13_192647.png)
content.html:
When building the gzweb project from source, icons used selecting objects within the web GUI fail to be generated when built on a headless machine. The need for x server session to host the gazebo rendering used when generating the icon set should be avoided.

In this case, the gzweb docker image built from OSRF's automatic registry on Docker Hub can not create icon sets, leaving the gzweb interface running from container using the distributed images rather devastated:

https://hub.docker.com/r/osrf/gazebo/

values.title: Wrong port announced in the terminal (7681 instead of 8080)

content.raw:
Both gzserver and gzweb print a message to the console that the server is listening on port 7681. 

For gzweb, it's because of this function call in ws_server.js:
*
server.listen(7681, function() {
    console.log((new Date()) + ' Server is listening on port 7681');*

However, the correct port is 8080, which is also mentioned in the documentation.
content.html:
Both gzserver and gzweb print a message to the console that the server is listening on port 7681.

For gzweb, it's because of this function call in ws_server.js: server.listen(7681, function() { console.log((new Date()) + ' Server is listening on port 7681');

However, the correct port is 8080, which is also mentioned in the documentation.

Since I haven't seen any note addressing that dependency-issue, I thought it could be a general bug.

Cheers,
Max

values.title: Not able to visualise ur10 in gzweb / gazebo7

content.raw:
I'm trying to visualise a UR10 in gzweb 2.0.0 and gazebo7. When spawning the simulation and gzweb, the real time and sim time are stuck at 0 and there's nothing under model as if Gazebo was down. 

I made a few modifications to the ur10 repository to try to reflect the different comments I found online as can be seen [here](https://github.com/shadow-robot/universal_robot/tree/F_gazebo_7_docker).

I added a [model.config](https://github.com/shadow-robot/universal_robot/blob/F_gazebo_7_docker/ur_description/model.config) file to the ur_description pointing to a static urdf for now (generated via xacro).

I also added the package to model conversion when loading the urdf for gazebo as can be seen [here](https://github.com/shadow-robot/universal_robot/blob/F_gazebo_7_docker/ur_gazebo/launch/ur10.launch#L27-L35). I tried without those lines and the simulation seems to be running in that case (model appearing in models, simulation time running etc...). But the ur10 isn't visualised either.

I'm building this in a docker container so you can find the exact steps I'm using [here](https://github.com/shadow-robot/universal_robot/blob/F_gazebo_7_docker/Dockerfile)

Finally this is how I start [gazebo and gzweb](https://github.com/shadow-robot/universal_robot/blob/F_gazebo_7_docker/entrypoint.sh).

Any idea?

Cheers,

Ugo
content.html:
I'm trying to visualise a UR10 in gzweb 2.0.0 and gazebo7. When spawning the simulation and gzweb, the real time and sim time are stuck at 0 and there's nothing under model as if Gazebo was down.

I made a few modifications to the ur10 repository to try to reflect the different comments I found online as can be seen here.

I added a model.config file to the ur_description pointing to a static urdf for now (generated via xacro).

I also added the package to model conversion when loading the urdf for gazebo as can be seen here. I tried without those lines and the simulation seems to be running in that case (model appearing in models, simulation time running etc...). But the ur10 isn't visualised either.

I'm building this in a docker container so you can find the exact steps I'm using here

Finally this is how I start gazebo and gzweb.

Any idea?

Cheers,

Ugo

content.raw:
Threejs is behind by 24 revisions -revision 62(current is 86) hasn't been updated since October, 2013-.
Threejs had so much improvements since then, so I filed the issue to start discussing upgrading it.
content.html: Threejs is behind by 24 revisions -revision 62(current is 86) hasn't been updated since October, 2013-. Threejs had so much improvements since then, so I filed the issue to start discussing upgrading it.

values.title: gazebo7 not working with gzweb branch upgrade-node

content.raw:
I use ubuntu 16.04 installed latest gazebo 7 (7.8.1) from osrf repo. And use gzweb `upgrade-node` branch. But after I run
```
gzserver --verbose /usr/share/gazebo-7/worlds/rubble.world &
start-gzweb.sh
```
Everything shows start correctly.

 When I open a browser with `localhost:8080`, just an empty world, not rubble.world.
content.html:
I use ubuntu 16.04 installed latest gazebo 7 (7.8.1) from osrf repo. And use gzweb upgrade-node branch. But after I run

gzserver --verbose /usr/share/gazebo-7/worlds/rubble.world &
start-gzweb.sh

Everything shows start correctly.

When I open a browser with localhost:8080, just an empty world, not rubble.world.

values.title: Translation and rotation doesn't work unless using the touch screen

content.raw:
Since no one talked about it, I guess this is an issue of computers with Touch screens, well or anything that does have both a touch screen and a mouse.

Translation and rotation doesn't work unless using the touch screen,
we should enable them to be used when a device is a computer, so gzgui should accept both touch and mouse controls.
